case_vignette: A man, aged 68 years, with no known history of atopy presents with a 4-month history of an itchy and burning rash on the legs that has been recurring every winter for the past 3 years. He notes that he had dry skin at baseline and did not use emollients, but he did try hydrocortisone 1% cream without improvement. Examination revealed ovoid, erythematous, well-marginated plaques on the lower legs and dorsal feet with variable scaling and focal weeping and crusting. There were no nail changes, and the rest of his skin examination was notable only for xerosis.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having an itchy and burning rash on my legs that comes back every winter for the past 3 years.
Is this rash associated with any other medical conditions or medications?
No, I don't have any known history of atopy or related medical conditions.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 68-year-old man.
Final Diagnosis: Winter itch or Senile xerosis.
